notes:
1. Concept

Thermal properties describe how a material responds to the application of heat.

2. Key Properties

  • Thermal Conductivity (k): A measure of a material's ability to conduct heat. Materials with high thermal conductivity (like metals) transfer heat quickly, while materials with low thermal conductivity (like foam insulation) transfer heat slowly. Units are W/m·K.
  • Coefficient of Thermal Expansion ($\alpha$): Describes how the size of an object changes with a change in temperature. Most materials expand when heated and contract when cooled. Units are 1/°C or 1/K.
  • Specific Heat ($c_p$): The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of a unit mass of a substance by one degree. A material with a high specific heat (like water) can absorb a lot of heat with only a small temperature change. Units are J/kg·K.
